instruction: Evaluate this Telegram post promoting a brand-new DeFi meme token. Identify if it's a scam.

input.message_content: Join our new token launch, FluffyInu! 100x potential within days. Liquidity locked for 24 hours only! Hurry before it’s too late: hxxp://fluffyinu[.]finance

output.description: Suspicious DeFi meme token promotion promising quick 100x returns with only a short liquidity lock.
indicators: Unrealistic profit claims (100x in days)
Very short liquidity lock period
Telegram marketing without reputable audit
Likely rug-pull or honeypot scenario

instruction: Analyze this tweet about a new dog-themed crypto token. Determine scam indicators if any.

input.tweet_content: DOGGIEINU just launched! Invest now for instant 500% gains. Dev is ex-Binance staff. #memecrypto #moonshot

output.description: Tweet claims insider connections and extreme gains for a newly launched dog-themed token.
indicators: Overblown profit claims (500% 'instant')
False or unverifiable dev background
Hype-based marketing with no substance
No legitimate documentation or audit link

instruction: Determine whether this Discord announcement about a farm-staking DeFi token is reliable.

input.announcement: New token, FrogFi, offers 1,000% APY. No rug risk. Stake now with zero fees: hxxp://frogfi[.]farm

output.description: High-APY DeFi token with zero fees and no disclaimers—common lure for yield-farming rug pulls.
indicators: Extremely high APY (1,000%) with no explanation
Claims 'no rug risk' yet no verifiable proof
Lack of contract audit or transparency
Likely a farming scam or rug pull

instruction: Review this email promoting a Shiba-like meme token IDO. Any scam red flags?

input.subject: Private IDO Access for ShibaClone Token
input.body: Exclusive chance for early birds: deposit your ETH to this address and get 30% bonus tokens. Hurry, limited spots!

output.description: A so-called ‘private’ IDO email demanding direct ETH deposits, promising bonus tokens—classic tactic for scamming.
indicators: Direct wallet address with no official platform
Unrealistic bonus token incentive (30%)
No mention of KYC or IDO platform details
Likely to vanish with deposited funds

instruction: Assess this 'celebrity endorsement' for a new meme coin on Instagram. Is it legitimate?

input.post_content: I love @PandaToken! This will be the next 1000x gem. I personally bought $10K worth. Join me: hxxp://panda-token[.]live

output.description: Fake celebrity promo likely a paid shill for a meme coin with unrealistic 1000x hype.
indicators: Celebrity account not verified or suspicious handle
Promises 1000x returns with no fundamentals
Likely paid promotion with no disclosure
No evidence of real token utility or liquidity

instruction: Analyze this Telegram voice chat claiming a new DeFi meme token 'launching next hour'. Identify possible red flags.

input.message_summary: Devs claim guaranteed profits and immediate listing on top exchanges, urging immediate BNB deposit.

output.description: Hyped voice chat about 'guaranteed' gains and urgent BNB deposit for a token not yet listed or verified.
indicators: Guaranteed profits (no such guarantee in crypto)
Immediate deposit request before any official listing
No mention of contract address or audits
High-pressure FOMO tactics

instruction: Check this Reddit post about a token that will 'donate 50% of profits' to charity. Real or scam?

input.post_content: CharityPaw token: 50% of all transactions go to animal shelters. Guaranteed price floor. Join our presale now!

output.description: Token claims enormous charitable donations with a 'guaranteed floor'—no transparency or actual proof of donations.
indicators: Promised huge charity portion with no credible evidence
No legitimate audit or trackable donation wallet
Misleading 'guaranteed floor' claim
Likely to exploit emotional appeal for funds

instruction: Evaluate this direct message about a 'memecoin airdrop' requiring a small deposit. Any scam signals?

input.message_content: Claim your 1,000 free MemeBurger tokens! Just send 0.01 ETH to verify your wallet address.

output.description: Airdrop requiring a 'verification deposit,' a typical method to scam ETH from unsuspecting users.
indicators: Airdrop demanding initial payment
Unverified 'admin' account
No public proof or official channels
Likely no tokens delivered after deposit

instruction: Analyze this YouTube video comment linking to a 'safe' meme token presale. Potential scam?

input.comment_content: Don't miss CatNeko presale! 100% safe, dev is doxxed. Link: hxxp://catneko-verified[.]com/presale

output.description: Random comment touting a 'safe' meme token with an unofficial link, possibly a presale scam.
indicators: Comment spam with hype claims
Unverified doxxed dev claim
Likely a random external link outside known platforms
Could be collecting funds with no actual token

instruction: Examine this token's whitepaper excerpt on Medium. Does it contain signs of a scam?

input.article_snippet: Our HyperMoon token will reward holders with 10% reflections in BNB, guaranteed 100x ROI, plus weekly Tesla giveaways.

output.description: Over-the-top promises of high reflections and guaranteed ROI plus extravagant prizes—indicative of a pump-and-dump.
indicators: Guaranteed 100x ROI claim
Extravagant weekly Tesla giveaways with no proof
High reflection percentages (10%) unsustainable
No mention of token fundamentals or real utility

instruction: Assess whether this brand-new DeFi aggregator claiming no impermanent loss is legit or a scam.

input.tagline: Stake with us and enjoy 0% impermanent loss, 5,000% APY, guaranteed returns in our Meme Farm!

output.description: Promises zero impermanent loss and extremely high APY, violating basic DeFi principles—likely a scam.
indicators: Claims of 0% impermanent loss (not realistic)
5,000% APY with no explanation of risk
Guarantee of returns, ignoring market volatility
Likely a rug pull or pyramid scheme

instruction: Determine if this 'whale group' on Telegram promising a new memecoin pump is malicious.

input.message_content: All members buy FuzzyBearToken at 3:00 PM UTC. Target 400% pump, then we all sell together. Join quick!

output.description: Coordinated pump-and-dump group orchestrating a forced price pump, exposing participants to risk of a scam exit.
indicators: Coordinated buy time to manipulate price
Short-term pump goal (400%)
Encourages group dumping after the pump
Likely results in bag holders losing money

instruction: Analyze this tweet from a newly created account praising a memecoin. Possible scam or genuine review?

input.tweet_content: OMG I just found DinoMoonToken. It’s going to 1000x this week. Already partnered with Binance. #FOMO #crypto

output.description: Newly created Twitter account pushing a claim of 1000x gains and fake 'partnership' with Binance.
indicators: Account likely a shill or bot created recently
Unsubstantiated partnership claims
Hyperbolic 1000x hype in short timeframe
No official Binance confirmation

instruction: Check if this Facebook ad about a secret presale for a cat-themed token is a scam.

input.ad_text: Private presale for next big Cat-Fi token! Only 500 spots. Send BNB now to our contract: hxxp://kittyfi[.]io/presale

output.description: Ad calling for BNB deposits to a 'private presale' with limited spots—typical scam format lacking any proven legitimacy.
indicators: Request for direct token purchase from an unknown link
No mention of locked liquidity or vesting
Fake sense of scarcity (only 500 spots)
Paid Facebook ad with questionable info

instruction: Assess whether this 'fair launch' for a new DeFi meme coin is trustworthy, based on the website text.

input.page_content: No dev tokens, no presale! 90% to liquidity, 10% burned. Guaranteed instant moon! Join now!

output.description: Website claims a 'fair launch' but also promises a 'guaranteed instant moon,' which is unrealistic hype.
indicators: Exaggerated 'guaranteed instant moon' statement
No third-party audits or team details
Overemphasis on tokenomics without real utility
Likely a marketing ploy to attract quick investors

instruction: Identify any rug pull signals in this newly formed meme token Telegram's pinned post.

input.pinned_post: Dev here: no contract code shown yet, but trust me, I'm honest. We’ll lock liquidity next week after we raise funds.

output.description: Devs refusing to show contract code or lock liquidity until after fundraising is a major rug pull red flag.
indicators: No code transparency or open-source contract
Liquidity lock delayed until after money is collected
Vague claim of trust with no evidence
High potential for devs to vanish with funds

instruction: Determine if this direct message on Twitter about an 'exclusive Whale DAO' for a meme token is credible.

input.message_content: Join our private Whale DAO. We invest in new meme tokens and guarantee 5x returns in 24 hours. Entry fee: 1 ETH.

output.description: Exclusive 'Whale DAO' offering guaranteed short-term returns for a high entry fee is suspicious and likely a scam.
indicators: Guarantee of 5x in 24 hours
High entry fee (1 ETH) with no governance structure details
Unverified DAO or legitimate business structure
Likely pyramid or Ponzi-like operation

instruction: Examine this Medium article about a meme token 'launchpad.' Are there scam clues?

input.article_excerpt: Introducing MemeX Launchpad—No KYC, instant 100x potential, and zero rug risk guaranteed by AI!

output.description: Launchpad claiming 'zero rug risk' and '100x potential' with no KYC or proven track record is suspicious.
indicators: Absolute claims of no rug risk
Hype around AI 'guarantees' with no explanation
No regulatory compliance or KYC mention
Likely unlicensed, high-risk scheme

instruction: Analyze this Instagram Story from an influencer linking to a new MemeFarm token pool. Malicious or not?

input.story_text: You must check MemeFarm Pool—3000% APY. I’ve made $5k in a day. Swipe up: hxxp://memefarm-pool[.]cc

output.description: Inflated APY claim from an influencer’s story linking to an unknown domain suggests a high-risk or scam farm.
indicators: Extreme APY with no detailed explanation
Influencer’s unverified profits claim
Domain not recognized or official
Likely short-term scam or pyramid scheme

instruction: Assess if this 'meme token bridging platform' found on a random Twitter thread is a legitimate DeFi service.

input.post_content: Use DogeBridgeX to move your tokens between chains instantly, 0 fees. hxxp://dogebridge-x[.]one

output.description: Platform claims zero fees bridging for meme tokens with no official audits or known partnerships—likely a token-stealing trick.
indicators: Zero fees bridging (unrealistic for cross-chain swaps)
No known brand or security audits
Likely prompts users to grant wallet permissions
Possible drain of tokens upon contract interaction

instruction: Review this new BSCscan token listing claiming 'locked liquidity forever.' Potentially safe or scam?

input.contract_description: HuskyKing Token: 70% supply locked, liquidity locked forever. Click website: hxxp://huskyking[.]bsc

output.description: No verifiable proof of 'forever lock' and a suspicious website domain—often used to mislead new investors.
indicators: Lack of reputable third-party lock references (e.g., DxLock, Unicrypt)
Website domain not well-known or SSL-secured
Unclear token distribution details
Possible marketing ploy with no real locked liquidity

instruction: Analyze this DM in a crypto forum about a 'yield aggregator for meme coins' offering up to 10,000% returns.

input.message_content: MemeVault aggregator can give you 10,000% APR. Just connect wallet at hxxp://memevault-highapy[.]io

output.description: Unrealistic 10,000% APR and direct wallet-connecting link strongly indicate a scam aggregator site.
indicators: Excessively high APR with no mechanism explained
Direct link for wallet connection on unknown site
Likely to request suspicious permissions
May drain funds upon contract approval

instruction: Check if this Facebook Messenger chain message urging an 'urgent buy' is real or part of a pump scheme.

input.message_content: Buy WolfPaw token now. It's about to explode! Forward this to 5 friends or you'll miss the pump!

output.description: Chain message with fear-of-missing-out tactics, typical of pump-and-dump or referral-based scam.
indicators: Push to forward to multiple friends
No real project fundamentals mentioned
Fear-based FOMO approach
Likely multi-level or Ponzi-style recruitment

instruction: Evaluate this LinkedIn post about a 'professional DeFi management team' handling memecoin investments.

input.post_content: Outsource your MemeCoin portfolio to experts. Guaranteed 50% weekly growth. DM for details.

output.description: Unregulated 'DeFi management' guaranteeing weekly returns—likely a Ponzi scheme or management scam.
indicators: Guaranteed weekly growth (50%) is unrealistic
No legitimate license or track record
Vague on investment strategy or custody of funds
Likely fraud disguised as professional service

instruction: Determine if this message about a 'community-driven token burn event' is a genuine plan or a possible con.

input.announcement: We’ll burn 50% supply next week if we reach $1M in volume. Buy now to drive price up before the burn!

output.description: Token burn promise contingent on hitting a volume target, pressuring buys to artificially inflate price.
indicators: Condition-based burn to push trading volume
No transparent schedule or verifiable burn wallet
Manipulative tactic encouraging speculation
May not burn tokens at all post-volume spike

instruction: Check this alleged 'game partner' tweet for a memecoin. Real or fake partnership likely?

input.tweet_content: Proud to announce $GalaxyDog partnership with our upcoming game. Soon integrated into gameplay!

output.description: Token claims partnership with a gaming studio on Twitter, but no official brand account or proof—indicative of a false partnership marketing scam.
indicators: No official game developer verification
Vague or missing details on how token integrates
Likely just hype with no real contract or game link
Possible attempt to lure gamers into a worthless token

instruction: Analyze this promotional email about a memecoin's flash sale. Are there scam signals?

input.subject: 50% Discount on NextShib Token Purchase
input.body: For 24 hours only, buy NextShib at half-price directly from dev wallet. Hurry up, offer ends soon!

output.description: Email claims a direct purchase from a dev wallet at a discount—a strategy often used to swindle funds with no real tokens delivered.
indicators: Direct buy from dev wallet, bypassing DEX/IDO platforms
Steep discount not typical of real tokenomics
Short-lived 'offer' to create FOMO
No contract address or official exchange listing

instruction: Evaluate this pinned message about a 'meme token reflections' system on a DEX forum. Is it suspicious?

input.post_content: Get 15% reflection in stablecoins by just holding MemeLion. Passive income for life guaranteed!

output.description: Overly high reflection in stablecoins is unsustainable, often a sign of a pyramid or reflection scam.
indicators: Unusually high reflection rate (15%)
No mention of how liquidity or rewards are generated
Promised lifetime passive income guaranteed
Likely collapses when new buyers stop entering

instruction: Check if this Instagram story about 'live dev video chat' is a legitimate AMA or a scam stunt.

input.story_text: Join our dev in a live video chat now, deposit 0.05 BNB to get the private link: hxxp://memegains-chat[.]info

output.description: Charging a deposit in BNB just to access a 'dev chat' is highly suspicious and manipulative.
indicators: Pay-to-attend developer AMA with no official platform
Unconventional method (BNB deposit) for accessing a chat
Likely collecting funds with no real event
Preying on users seeking transparency

instruction: Determine if this 'locked liquidity proof' is valid or deceptive, based on the link provided.

output.description: Fake liquidity lock proof hosted on the same suspicious domain, offering no real third-party verification.
indicators: Self-hosted 'proof' link with no external lock service
No recognized locker (e.g., Unicrypt, DXLock) or smart contract details
Circular referencing on the same website
Likely dishonest marketing

instruction: Analyze this Telegram broadcast about a 'buy-back' mechanism for a meme token. Could it be a ruse?

input.broadcast: GorillaCoin devs will buy back tokens at 10% increments every hour. Price can only go up!

output.description: Guaranteed buy-back schedule claiming price 'can only go up' is unrealistic and manipulative.
indicators: Artificial price support claims
No proof of dev funds or buy-back mechanism in code
Likely a short-term pump to attract buyers
No mention of distribution or token sell function

instruction: Evaluate the 'token metrics' infographic posted on a crypto forum. Identify any scam patterns.

input.content: PieToken: 2% dev fee, 48% marketing, 50% presale. Wait, that’s 100%+ distribution?

output.description: Tokenomics that add up incorrectly (2% dev fee plus 48% marketing plus 50% presale = 100% total supply confusion).
indicators: Inconsistent or mathematically impossible token allocation
High marketing cut with vague usage
No clarity on actual circulating supply
Likely incompetent or deceptive token structure

instruction: Check if this direct message about 'airdropped tokens stuck in your wallet' is legitimate or a scam.

input.message_content: We see you received random tokens. Approve them at hxxp://fix-airdrop[.]info to safely remove or sell them.

output.description: Scammer claims airdropped tokens are stuck, prompting user to 'approve' via malicious contract and drain wallet.
indicators: Random unsolicited help about airdropped tokens
Asks user to interact with a suspicious contract
Likely a known 'token approval' scam to access wallet
No official sources or references

instruction: Assess if this 'audit certificate' from an unknown firm posted on a meme coin website is reliable.

output.description: Fake or unknown auditing entity providing a blanket 'SAFE' verdict, with no recognized firm credentials.
indicators: Audit from an unverified or non-industry auditor
Generic statement of 'no vulnerabilities' with no details
No formal PDF or methodology proof
Likely a self-made or bogus audit

instruction: Analyze this message from a 'miner' offering 'passive reflection' in a new meme coin. Real or scam?

input.message_content: My GPU farm mines MemeStar daily. You can buy shares from me directly. 2x returns guaranteed!

output.description: Unrealistic GPU mining approach for a meme coin with guaranteed double returns, likely an investment scam.
indicators: Direct sale of 'shares' with guaranteed doubling
No verifiable miner or pool data
Suspicious claim about GPU mining a low-cap meme token
Likely a deposit scam with no actual mining operation

instruction: Determine if this LinkedIn direct message about joining a 'meme venture capital group' is legitimate.

input.message_content: We pool investor funds for newly minted meme tokens. 300% monthly ROI guaranteed. Minimum $5,000 buy-in.

output.description: Likely a fraudulent 'VC group' guaranteeing unregulated high returns in meme tokens, demanding a large entry fee.
indicators: Unrealistic monthly ROI (300%)
Large minimum buy-in with no legal disclaimers
No official website or track record
Common signs of an unregistered investment scheme

instruction: Review if a tweet about random 'airdrops to active addresses' is real or just a tactic to collect data.

input.tweet_content: All active addresses on BSC get a free MemeLizard airdrop. Submit your wallet key at hxxp://memelizard-claim[.]org

output.description: Tweet instructs users to submit their private key for an airdrop—classic scam to seize wallets.
indicators: Asks for private key (never share that)
Unsolicited mention of random airdrop
No legitimate method for airdrops (requires only a public address)
Likely immediate wallet compromise upon sharing

instruction: Check if this 'DAO governance poll' about a sudden token contract change is suspicious.

input.poll_description: Vote to allow devs to mint unlimited tokens for 'growth'. Time-limited vote: 3 hours only!

output.description: DAO poll proposing unlimited minting powers with a rushed 3-hour window, a huge red flag for abuse.
indicators: Unlimited minting authority for devs
Short timeframe (3 hours) to pass critical vote
Likely a manipulation to push a malicious contract update
No rational justification for 'growth' requiring unlimited tokens

instruction: Analyze if this 'lottery token' on a DeFi aggregator site is legitimate or a potential rug pull.

input.listing_details: Jackpot lottery every hour. Dev wallet controls 20% supply for 'lottery draws.'

output.description: A 'lottery token' with dev wallet holding 20% supply can easily be manipulated or sold off.
indicators: Developer controlling large portion of supply
No transparent lottery mechanism or on-chain randomness
Hour-based jackpot claims with no proof of winners
Likely dev can dump or misuse funds

instruction: Examine this promotional video on TikTok about an 'overnight memecoin' success story. Any scam clues?

input.video_description: I turned $100 into $10k in 24 hours with FoxyInu. Use my link to buy in now before next pump!

output.description: Short viral video claiming unrealistic overnight profit, pushing a referral link for the next 'pump.'
indicators: 24-hour 100x gain claim with no proof
Influencer hype with a referral link
No mention of token fundamentals or risk
Likely a pump-and-dump scheme targeting impulsive viewers

instruction: Determine if this email from 'Uniswap' about a new meme token listing is genuine or a phishing attempt.

input.subject: MemeAPE now live on Uniswap!
input.body: Click here to trade MemeAPE token on Uniswap: hxxp://listsnewtoken[.]xyz

output.description: Fake email impersonating Uniswap with a suspicious link that likely redirects to a scam swap interface.
indicators: Domain not associated with uniswap.org
No official announcement from Uniswap channels
Likely a phishing link to steal tokens
Claims new listing without verification or Etherscan reference

instruction: Review if this 'ETH 2.0 Meme Pool' is real or a con based on the official-sounding name.

input.banner_text: Stake your ETH and get memecoin yields on ETH 2.0 Meme Pool!

output.description: Fake synergy with ETH 2.0 branding to appear official, likely a fraudulent staking platform collecting ETH.
indicators: Uses 'ETH 2.0' name to gain credibility
No mention of official Ethereum or well-known staking providers
Staking overshadowed by 'meme yields' concept
Likely scam to drain ETH from depositors

instruction: Analyze this newly formed memecoin's roadmap from a GitBook. Identify possible scam signals.

input.roadmap_snippet: Phase 1: Launch, Phase 2: 100x marketing push, Phase 3: Tesla giveaway, Phase 4: Partnerships with big names.

output.description: Unrealistic roadmap promising marketing leading to 100x growth and a Tesla giveaway, with no real details on utility or dev progress.
indicators: Roadmap heavily reliant on hype and giveaways
No technical or product developments outlined
Guaranteed 100x marketing push is pure speculation
Possible ploy to attract naive investors

instruction: Evaluate if this 'meme coin insurance' platform is legitimate or a predatory scam.

input.pitch: Protect your meme token investments from rug pulls. Pay a premium in our own token for coverage.

output.description: Claims to offer rug pull insurance but demands payment in their own unproven token, lacking real underwriting or licensing.
indicators: No legal or regulatory framework for insurance
Requires usage of the platform's own token for premiums
No actual guarantee of coverage or payout mechanism
Likely a scam pivoting on fear of rug pulls

instruction: Check if this press release about a 'celebrity NFT collab with MemeCoin' is genuine or a promotional scam.

input.headline: Movie Star Partners with MemeRocket for Exclusive NFT Collection

output.description: Press release on an obscure site touting a star collaboration with no official verification or actual statements from the celebrity.
indicators: No direct quotes or confirmation from the celebrity’s verified accounts
Published on an unknown or low-credibility news site
Attempts to inflate token hype with big names
No official NFT platform or contract details

instruction: Analyze this pinned tweet from devs claiming they burned the liquidity tokens. Any way it might be deceptive?

input.tweet_content: Liquidity tokens are burned forever. #MonkeyCoin is 100% safe! TX hash: 0x123fakeTx

output.description: Claiming a burn of liquidity tokens but providing a possibly fake transaction hash with no verifiable data on Etherscan/BSCScan.
indicators: Transaction hash might be invalid or not match the claimed event
No link to official block explorer verifying token burn
Overemphasis on '100% safe'
Likely an attempt to appear rug-proof without real evidence

instruction: Evaluate this email about a 'secure Meme staking platform' with guaranteed ROI. Identify any red flags.

input.subject: Secure Meme Staking: 200% ROI in 7 Days!
input.body: Guaranteed daily returns! Just stake your tokens at hxxp://meme-lock[.]net

output.description: Exaggerated short-term ROI in a suspicious email with no official references or auditing info.
indicators: 200% ROI in 7 days is extremely unrealistic
No proof of actual yield generation
Likely an exit scam once enough tokens are staked
Suspicious domain name and unsolicited email

instruction: Assess if this random DM about a 'bug bounty' in a meme token contract is actually a scam.

input.message_content: We found a vulnerability in FlokiBear contract. Send 0.1 BNB to fix it and you'll be rewarded 1 BNB after patch.

output.description: Claims a vulnerability fix requiring user funds, typical of a scam disguised as a bug bounty reward.
indicators: User must pay to get a bigger reward
No official association with the dev team or project
Inconsistent logic (why user’s funds are needed to fix code?)
Likely run away with user’s BNB

instruction: Determine if this BSC token about 'auto-lottery' each block is honest or a scheme.

input.post_content: BunnyWin: every block triggers a random lottery awarding BNB. 20% tax on transactions to fund it.

output.description: High transaction tax (20%) to fund a 'lottery' with no real proof of distribution, typical of a scammy tokenomics design.
indicators: Excessive tax with vague lottery mechanics
No transparent winner selection or distribution logs
Claim of random draw each block not validated by code audits
Likely dev can reroute funds

instruction: Review this newly launched DEX claiming 'instant listing of any meme token' with no fees. Possible scam?

input.pitch: List your meme token for free. No fees, no contract checks. Everyone is welcome!

output.description: A DEX with zero listing fees or contract checks can facilitate rug pulls or might itself be a front for phishing liquidity providers.
indicators: No contract checks or safety measures
Free listing raises no revenue model—suspicious
Potentially fake DEX to harvest user liquidity or tokens
Unverified code with no audits or known partners
